sections.heading: Overview
content: Marcia Lattanzi-Licht, MA, RN, LPC, is an internationally known educator, lecturing before professional groups and audiences in forty-three states, Canada, Europe and Australia. She has appeared on the Today Show , MSNBC and numerous other television and radio programs. A popular keynote speaker, she also conducts seminars and retreats for hospices, hospitals, law enforcement agencies, local and county governments, universities, professional groups and corporations.

An early voice for hospice care, Lattanzi-Licht was a co-founder of Hospice of Boulder County, Colorado, and the originator and director of its nationally recognized education and bereavement programs. Publishing widely in the areas of coping with professional stress, loss and bereavement care, she also specializes in team building, staff support and communication programs. She is the principal author of The Hospice Choice: In Pursuit of a Peaceful Death, and is also the principal investigator in the Colorado Bereavement Services Project, studying bereavement risk assessment and outcomes. Lattanzi-Licht was a panelist on the Hospice 2003 Teleconference Coping with Public Tragedy , and is co-editor of the book by that title (2003).

A licensed counselor, Lattanzi-Licht has maintained a private psychotherapy practice for more than seventeen years. She also currently works as the professional education specialist with the National Hospice and Palliative Care Organization.

Lattanzi-Licht is the recipient of numerous awards, including an honorary doctorate in humane letters from the University of Colorado (2005), the 1984 Winston Churchill Traveling Fellowship, and the 2002 Association for Death Education and Counseling Educator Award. In 1995 she received a Heart of Hospice Award from the National Hospice Organization for her repeated outstanding achievements in hospice, and contributions with impact beyond hospice. She has been honored as a 1985 Boulder Pacesetter and received the Boulder County District Attorney's highest award in 1988, the Distinguished Service Award, for her work with victims of crime. In 1997 she wrote the script and syllabus for Difficult Conversations: Talking About the End of Life and Hospice Care , one of three videos in the AMA award winning "Care Beyond Cure" physician education series.
